\section{Self-assessment exercises}

The following exercises are designed to provide practice at problem-solving
based on the material in this module. Solutions are provided at the end of the module.
Additional exercises are available in the next section and in the textbook.


\begin{exercises}

\item Suppose the pdf of $X$ is given by
\[
   f_X(x) = \begin{cases}
                x/2 & \text{$0<x<2$}\\
                0 & \text{otherwise}
             \end{cases}
\]
\begin{enumerate}
\item Find the pdf of $Y=X^3$ using the distribution function
method. \item Find the pdf of $Y=X^3$ using the change of variable
method.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{answer}
Note that for $0<x<2$ where $X$ is defined, the transformation
$Y=X^3$ is a one-to-one transformation. The inverse transform is
$X=Y^{1/3}$ and so $Y$ is defined for $0<y<8$.

\begin{enumerate}
\item
$F_Y(y) = \Pr{Y\le y}
   = \Pr{X^3 \le y} = \Pr{X\le y^{1/3}}= F_X( y^{1/3})
   = \int_{u=0}^{y^{1/3}} u/2\,du = u^2/4\Big|_{u=0}^{u=y^{1/3}} = y^{2/3}/4.$
The pdf is then found by differentiating: $\frac{d}{dy} y^{2/3}/4
= y^{-1/3}/6$. So the pdf of $Y$ is
\[
   f_Y(y) = \begin{cases}
               y^{-1/3}/6 & \text{for $0<y<8$}\\
               0 & \text{otherwise}
            \end{cases}
\]

\item Note that $w(y) = y^{1/3}$ so that $w'(y) = y^{-2/3}3$.
\begin{align*}
   f_Y(y)
   &= f_X(y) |J|\\
   &= y^{1/3}/2 \times \overbrace{y^{-2/3}/3}^{|J|} \\
   &= y^{-1/3}/6.
\end{align*}
So again the pdf of $Y$ is
\[
   f_Y(y) = \begin{cases}
               y^{-1/3}/6 & \text{for $0<y<8$}\\
               0 & \text{otherwise}
            \end{cases}
\]

\end{enumerate}
\end{answer}

\item The discrete bivariate random vector $(X_1, X_2)$ has the
joint pf
\[
   f_{X_1, X_2}(x_1, x_2) = \begin{cases}
                               (2x_1+x_2)/14 & \text{for $x_1=0, 1; x_2=0,1$}\\
                               0 & \text{elsewhere}
                             \end{cases}
\]
Consider the transformations
\begin{align*}
   Y_1 &= X_1 + X_2 \\
   Y_2 &= \phantom{X_1+{}} X_2
\end{align*}

\begin{enumerate}
   \item
   Determine the joint pf of $(Y_1, Y_2)$.
   %       Y1=1   Y1=2  Y1=3
   %Y2=0   2/14   4/14  0
   %Y2=1   0      3/14  5/14

   \item
   Deduce the distribution of $Y_1$.
   % 2/14 if Y1=1
   % 7/14 (=3/14 + 4/14) if Y1=2
   % 5/14 if Y1=3
\end{enumerate}

\begin{answer}
This one is much harder than it looks, mainly since $Y_1$ takes
the values $1$ and $2$ for $Y_2=0$; but $Y_1$ takes the values $2$
and $3$ for $Y_2=1$.


The joint pf is
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{cccc}
   & $Y_1=1$ & $Y_1=2$ & $Y_1=3$ \\
$Y_2=0$ & $2/14$ & $4/14$ & $0$ \\
$Y_2=1$ & $0$ & $3/14$ & $5/14$
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

$f_{Y_1}(y=1) = 2/14$; $f_{Y_1}(y=2) = 7/14$; $f_{Y_1}(y=3) =
5/14$.
\end{answer}

\item Consider $n$ random variables $X_i$ such that $X_i \sim
\text{Gam}(\alpha_i, \beta)$. Determine the distribution of
$Y=\sum_{i=1}^n X_i$.

\begin{answer}
$Y \sim\text{Gam}(\sum\alpha, \beta)$.
\end{answer}

\end{exercises}

\section{Exercises}

\begin{exercises}


\item
If $X$ is a random variable with probability function
\[ \Pr{X=x} = {4\choose x} (.2)^x(0.8)^{4-x},
\quad x=0,1,2,3,4, \]
find the probability function of the random variable defined by $Y=\sqrt{X}$.

\begin{answer}
See Example~\ref{EG:7.1}.
\end{answer}


\item
Given the random variable $X$ with probability function
\[ \Pr{X=x} = \frac{x^2}{30} \quad x=1,2,3,4, \]
find the probability function of $Y= (X-3)^2$.

\begin{answer}
The transformation is not 1-1. See Example~\ref{EG:trans2}.
$\Pr{Y=0}=9/30$, $\Pr{Y=1}=20/30$, $\Pr{Y=2}=1/30$.
\end{answer}


\item A random variable $X$ has pdf given by
\[ f_X(x) = 1, \quad 0<x<1 \]
Find the pdf of the random variable $Y$ defined by $Y=-2\log_e(X)$.

\begin{answer}
Use Theorem~\ref{TM:7.1}. $g(y)=\ds{\frac{1}{2}e^{-y/2}}$, $0<y<\infty$
\end{answer}


\item The random variable $X$ has pdf
\[ f_X(x)=\frac{1}{\pi(1+x^2)}, \quad -\infty<x<\infty \]
Find the pdf of $Y$ where $Y=X^2$.

\begin{answer}
Transformation is not 1-1. See Example~\ref{EG:7.6}.
$f_Y(y)=\ds{\frac{1}{\pi \sqrt{y}(1+y)}}$, $0<y<\infty$.
\end{answer}


\item
If $W$ has a chi-square distribution with $\nu$ degrees of freedom
and has pdf
\[ f_W(w)= \frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2}w}w^{\frac{1}{2}\nu-1}}{2^{\frac{1}{2}\nu}
       \Gamma{\left(\frac{1}{2}\nu\right)}}, \quad w>0 \]
find (a) the mode (b) $\E(W)$ (c) $\var(W)$ (d) mgf

\begin{answer}
(a) $\nu-2$ (b) $\nu$ (c) $2\nu$ (d) $(1 - 2t )^{-\nu/2}$
\end{answer}


\item A random variable $X$ has distribution function
\[F_X(x)=\frac{2x+1}{2}, \quad -0.5<x<0.5 \]
\begin{enumerate}
\item Find the distribution function, $F_Y(y)$, of the random variable $Y=4-X^2$.
\item Hence find the pdf of $Y$, $f_Y(y)$.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{answer}
(a) $F_Y(y) =\Pr{Y \le y} = 1 - 2\sqrt{4-y}$, $3.75<y<4$
      (b) $f_Y(y)=(4-y)^{-1/2}$
\end{answer}


\item
Suppose a projectile is fired at an angle $\theta$ from the
horizontal with a velocity $v$. The horizontal distance that the
projectile travels, $R$, is given by
\[
   R = \frac{v^2}{g} \sin 2\theta ,
\]
where $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity (usually set at
$g\approx 9.8 \hbox{m}/\hbox{s}^2$).
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $\theta$ is uniformly distributed over the range $(0,
\pi/4)$, find the probability density function of $R$. \item
Sketch the pdf of $R$ over a suitable range for $v=12$ and using
$g\approx 9.8$.
\end{enumerate}

\item Most computers have facilities to generate continuous
uniform random numbers between zero and one, say $X$.  When
exponential random numbers are needed, they are usually obtained
from $X$ using the transformation $Y=-\alpha\ln X$.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item
    Show that $Y$ has an exponential distribution
    and determine its parameters.

    \item
    Deduce the mean and variance of $Y$.
\end{enumerate}

\item
Consider a random variable $W$ for which $\Pr{W=2}=1/6$,
$\Pr{W=-2}=1/3$ and $\Pr{W=0}=1/2$.

\begin{enumerate}

    \item
    Plot the probability function of $W$.

    \item
    Find the mean and variance of $W$.

    \item
    Determine the distribution of $V=W^2$.

    \item
    Find the distribution function of $W$.

\end{enumerate}



\end{exercises}
